stream_context.summary: Kaze works on designing and greyboxing the 'snowman cave' level. He focuses on creating distinct platforming sections (a slide, a void room, cliff climbing), debugging snowman AI, and refining an elevator camera effect. He also discusses his creative philosophy, team collaboration, and personal life, including the imminent birth of his daughter.

development_findings.summary: The 'snowman cave' level is being designed with several distinct sections: a slide, a platforming area over a void, a cliff-climbing segment, and a final treasure room.
development_findings.quote: One room I want is kind of like a slide that you climb up. And there's going to be the snowman attacking you on the slide. Another one is platforms over a void and you kind of climb between the platforms.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning a significant rework of the game's shadow system. The new approach involves making the shadow a separate object from Mario to resolve issues where it doesn't render on the correct surface.
development_findings.quote: My idea for the shadows is that it's actually going to be a whole separate object, separate from Mario... so it can have a different floor from Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is strictly adhering to the original N64's 64MB cartridge size limit as a core creative constraint, viewing it as essential to the project's integrity.
development_findings.quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating? You see the issue. I don't want to finish the game and then people are like, oh, yeah, but to use more memory, though.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to release a demo of the first course and use a Google document to gather detailed community feedback on game feel, physics, and camera to make fine-tuned adjustments.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna have like a Google document where people can answer all kinds of questions about what they think of different parts of the physics and stuff.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's level design process involves 'greyboxing', where he first builds and tests the core platforming layout with simple, untextured geometry before the final art pass.
development_findings.quote: I call it the case method because I just made it up.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has developed a streamlined workflow that allows him to deploy and test new builds on original N64 hardware almost instantly via a batch file.
development_findings.quote: Look how fast n64 testing is now that I have to set up i just click the bat and it's there it's right on my n64 isn't that fucking sick

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to create an open-source project after RTYI is finished to port all of the engine optimizations he developed back into the vanilla Super Mario 64 codebase for the community to use.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that boredom is a valuable and necessary state for fostering creativity, contrasting it with the modern desire for constant stimulation.
context_findings.quote: People don't enjoy being bored enough they don't appreciate the value that comes out of just being bored sometimes just being with your own thoughts and nothing else and that's the problem.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he spent four years in extreme social isolation, an experience that he says made him 'go a bit crazy' but also gave him a profound appreciation for small, simple sensory experiences.
context_findings.quote: for like four years i just lived like by myself alone without ever talking to anyone and that does make you go a bit crazy... I stood there and was like, man, this is nice. I like just smelling the sausage. You just start appreciating like the smallest things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze announced that he and his wife, Zeina, are expecting their daughter, Reyna, to be born in five days, which will affect his work schedule.
context_findings.quote: just so you guys know, in five days, my daughter is likely going to be born. Meaning I might not be able to stream next week.

context_findings.summary: Kaze perceives his relationship with Nintendo as antagonistic, stating they 'hate' him and have previously taken down 70 of his YouTube videos.
context_findings.quote: They fucking hate me... They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is planning to scale his YouTube content production by hiring a video editor, believing he has enough material for 70-80 videos on Mario 64 and could potentially reach one million subscribers.
context_findings.quote: I feel like we could hit a million subs if we actually went in hard on that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze stated that if he were to develop a commercial game, he would use Unreal Engine over Unity, citing its financial stability and his aversion to Unity's recent policy changes.
context_findings.quote: If I was going to make a game, it would be an Unreal Engine... Unreal Engine is backed by Fortnite money, so what are you going to do?

biobak.summary: Biobak's role is to take Kaze's initial 3D models and refine them, improving their visual quality for the final game.
biobak.quote: we got a Mario back helping with all the models. He whenever I'm done with the model, he looks over it again and makes it look a lot better.

badub.summary: Badub is confirmed to be the composer for the project.

zeina.summary: Zeina's primary role on the project is creating animations, and she also contributes concept art.
zeina.quote: we got Zayna helping with a lot of stuff. Mostly like concept art and stuff... Oh yeah, animations are the biggest one she's doing.

zeina.summary: Kaze's personal and professional lives are intertwined; he attributes his fatigue during the stream to frequent swimming trips with Zeina that week.
zeina.quote: Dude, we went swamming so much this week. Me and Zeina. We went like every day. Maybe that's why I'm feeling so tired today.

key_stories.title: The 64MB Constraint
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains his firm commitment to keeping the project within the N64's original 64-megabyte cartridge size limit. He views exceeding this limitation as 'cheating' and undermining the challenge of the project, even though more space is technically available with modern flash carts.
key_stories.challenge: A chat member questioned why Kaze doesn't use more ROM space since modern hardware allows for it.
key_stories.process: Kaze articulated his philosophy that adhering to the original hardware's constraints is a core part of the project's identity. He explained that using more memory would open the project to criticism that it didn't achieve its goals under the same conditions as the original developers.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze reaffirmed his design principle to stay within the 64MB limit, establishing it as a key creative constraint for the project to maintain its integrity and challenge.
key_stories.key_quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating? You see the issue. I don't want to finish the game and then people are like, oh, yeah, but to use more memory, though.

key_stories.title: The Value of Boredom
key_stories.summary: Kaze discusses his philosophy on the importance of boredom for creativity. He contrasts this with the modern need for constant stimulation and reflects on a period of his own life where extreme isolation led to a deeper appreciation for simple experiences.
key_stories.challenge: Responding to a chat member's desire for constant stimulation and distraction.
key_stories.process: Kaze explained that the brain is meant to be creative when bored. He shared a personal anecdote about living in extreme isolation for four years, which forced him to find value in simple things and led to a profound sense of appreciation.
key_stories.outcome: He concludes that boredom is a valuable state that people should learn to enjoy, as it fosters creativity and a deeper appreciation for the world.
key_stories.key_quote: People don't enjoy being bored enough they don't appreciate the value that comes out of just being bored sometimes just being with your own thoughts and nothing else and that's the problem.

key_stories.title: Designing the Snowman Cave
key_stories.summary: Kaze brainstorms and begins greyboxing the 'Snowman Cave' level. He establishes the core concepts for the level's sections and then works through a specific cliff-climbing area, iterating on the platforming to ensure multiple paths and a good feel.
key_stories.challenge: To design and prototype a compelling and varied ice-themed level from scratch.
key_stories.process: Kaze first brainstormed the core concepts for the level's sections. He then built a 'greybox' prototype of the cliff-climbing area using simple rock geometry, tested it, identified gameplay issues like getting stuck, and iterated on the geometry to improve player flow and add multiple paths.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a functional and fun-to-navigate prototype for the cliff-climbing section and established a clear plan for the remaining sections of the level (slide, void room, treasure room).
key_stories.key_quote: I like this section. Obviously it's butt ugly, but other than that I think it's good.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a 4-year period of extreme social isolation that made him 'go a bit crazy' and led to a new appreciation for life. He alluded to it being a formative and difficult experience.
questions: You spoke about a four-year period of isolation. How did that time shape your creative process and your philosophy on game design?
You mentioned it made you 'go a bit crazy' and created a false memory. Could you elaborate on how that experience impacted you personally and creatively?
How did you transition out of that period, and how does it influence your work and collaborations today?

open_questions.context: Kaze described the high-level roles of his team: he does initial design, Biobak refines models, Badub makes music, and Zeina does animation. The actual hand-off, feedback, and collaborative process remains unclear.
questions: Can you describe the workflow between you and Biobak? How does a model go from your 'greybox' to a final, polished asset?
What is the feedback loop like with Badub for music? Do you provide a level and ask for a theme, or is it more collaborative?
How does Zeina's concept art influence your level design, and at what stage does she create animations for new characters or actions?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he plans to fix shadows by making them a separate object from Mario. When a knowledgeable chatter asked for more detail, he dismissed the question, saying, 'It's complicated. Don't worry about it.'
questions: Can you walk us through the technical challenge with the original shadow system in the Mario 64 engine?
What specific visual problems were you seeing, for example with the elevator or moving platforms?
How does creating a separate shadow object solve these problems, and what new complexities does that introduce?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that Nintendo 'hates' him and has taken down 70 of his videos. He did not elaborate on the specifics of these takedowns or how this history affects his current work.
questions: You mentioned Nintendo took down 70 of your videos. Can you tell us the story behind that? What was the communication like?
How has this history with Nintendo influenced your design or distribution decisions for 'Return to Yoshi's Island'?
Does this create any fear or concern for you or the team regarding the project's eventual release?
